No. Not yet, anyway. I dunno, I've got tunnels all over the place, but I can't seem to find it.
Find what?
The transmat shaft. They all use it. The Shadow and all his horribles. The trouble is, you see, my Tardis is back on Zeos.
Yes, but where does it lead?
Have a look.
Well, Doctor, welcome to my world.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor picks up some bits and pieces that Drax has lying around.

Dialogue.Line: Aren't they stabiliser components?
Yeah, they are.
But you said your Tardis was parked on Zeos.
Yeah, well, I took the stabiliser out. Needs a bit of work.
How long have you been here?
About five years. After the war started.
Five years? For five years you've had a dimensional stabiliser virtually intact and you haven't managed to escape?
I told you, it needed work.
Oh, come on, Drax! You could have repaired that and long-dogged it out of here years ago.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor tries to look inside his collar.

Dialogue.Line: Here, what's the game? Oh, I get it. You think I'm in with the Shadow, don't you.
Aren't you?
Now would I.
Yes, you would. What's he offered you?
Nothing.
Are you about to suggest that you and I make a run for it out of here in my Tardis?
Well, it's a good idea.
Oh yes, it's a very good idea, you and me in my Tardis. And what happens then when we're inside, eh? Sock full of sand, lead pipe and you away with the Key to Time, am I right, Drax?
Look, I didn't know it was going to be you, did I. He threatened me with the chop, didn't he. He said I was the only one who could get hold of it.
If you had, do you think he'd let you get away? You'd be in for the chop, too.
Yeah, I would, wouldn't I.
Of course you would. So why don't you help me? I mean, together we stand a slight chance. And after all, we are Time Lords, you and I. Class of ninety two. If we don't stick together, who will?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Astra watches impassively while Romana is tortured.

Dialogue.Line: Enough.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana falls out of the interrogation booth.

Dialogue.Line: She has told me everything she knows, and it is not enough. Still the cursed Doctor stands between me and the Key. We shall see what the Doctor is prepared to offer for your life.
I'm not afraid to die.
K9? K9 [on screen]: Master.
To the Doctor. K9 [on screen]: Affirmative, master.
No, K9!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Drax is trying to repair the distress beacon with the Doctor looking over his shoulder.

Dialogue.Line: Try synaptic adhesion.
Synaptic adhesion? It's the chronostat. Always is.
I think it's synaptic adhesion.
Look, I've done thousands of these. Thousands.
All right. Got to be synaptic adhesion. All right, all right, I'll leave it to you, shall I.
Yeah.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor removes the cover to another small tunnel.

Dialogue.Line: Drax, where does this lead?
Upper level. Watch out for the mutes.
Yeah. Yeah, of course.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor crawls out.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor? I have you on scan, Doctor.
Doctor?
Turn left now. Turn right now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor arrives at a grating in the tunnel wall.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor.
Yes, old friend? K9: I have a message for you.
I can't hear. Can you come a bit closer?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hits the grating, which hits K9 on the nose.

Dialogue.Line: Such actions warrant immediate death, which I shall execute.
Oh, K9. K9: Here is a message for you. Doctor, Romana is with my master.
Ah. K9: He wishes to know if you will exchange the Key to Time for the life of Romana. End of message. Your reply, please. Waiting.
Tell your master I shall give his offer serious consideration.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pushes the grating aside, goes behind K9 and pushes him down the small tunnel into Drax's cell. Crash.

Dialogue.Line: Hey!
Yes?
What's this heap of junk?
That's my computer.
Eh?
Drax, I've got no time to explain. Remove the control device from under his chin, all right? DRAX [OC}: Oh, er, ah, right. Done it. Now what?
Now nothing. Carry on with the stabiliser. I'll be back soon, I hope. Bye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Exploring a tunnel, the Doctor is taken prisoner by one of the Shadow's minions.
K9 is lying on his side.

Dialogue.Line: Attention! Attention!

What's that? K9: Malfunction in drive systems. Attention required immediately. DRAX: Oh, it's you. I'm busy. K9: Essential restored to vertical position. Alternative is your obliteration. DRAX: Leave me alone.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 starts emitting a distress sound.

Dialogue.Line: All right, all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He puts K9 back on its wheels.

Dialogue.Line: That better? K9: Affirmative.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 sucks his laser back in.

Dialogue.Line: Blimey, it's a dog. Who's a little tin dog, then? K9: Your silliness is noted. Drive systems regenerating.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Drax returns to his repair work.

Dialogue.Line: I don't get it. It's the chronostat. It always is. K9: Negative. It is a question of synaptic adhesion.
Not you and all.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana is back in the interrogation booth.

Dialogue.Line: The Key to Time, Doctor. (silence) Then you can watch your assistant suffer.
I refuse to negotiate in an atmosphere of threat.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana gets zapped.

Dialogue.Line: No, no, stop! Stop!
Doctor, no. Don't give in to him. It doesn't matter what happens to me.
Well of course it matters. You have the sixth piece, I take it?
It is here.
Well, I'd like to see it, if it's possible.
You have already seen it.
Ah. Yes. If I bring the other five pieces
Yes?
What is it you have in mind? I mean, what do you intend to do?
Come now, Doctor, you know who I am.
Yes. I suppose you realise I've rigged things so that Atrios and Zeos are protected.
Your puny time loop.
Yes, my puny. Well, it may be puny but it works. If you break that, millions of people will die.
That has always been our intention. This pathetic little war is but a rehearsal for our grand design.
Our?
You have your Guardian and I have mine. You and I are on the same quest, Doctor, but whereas you have been scavenging across space and time, I have located the sixth piece here.
Oh.

Your are inferior, just as your powers are inferior. Once we have the Key to Time, we shall set not two small planets but the two halves of the entire cosmos at war, and their mutual destruction will be music in our ears. Unlike others, it is not power we seek, but destruction that we glory in. Fetch the Key.
Very well.
No! Doctor!
Bwahahahahahahaha!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Repairs are complete.

Dialogue.Line: It's working. You were right, Doc. Synaptic adhesion. K9: Correct.
You don't know what the Doctor wants it for, do you? K9: Negative.
Well, I'd better go and find out. Stay, boy.
Now, my Princess, your work is done. Your destiny is at hand.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Shadow removes the control device from Astra's throat, and she comes to herself again.

Dialogue.Line: Who are you?
The Shadow.
The Shadow that accompanies you all.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Drax waits until the Doctor and his escort passes the top of the little tunnel, then follows them at a discreet distance.
Drax turns the device on himself, and shrinks. The minion looks round for them.

Dialogue.Line: Over here, Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A tiny Doctor runs towards where Drax is hiding in a little crevice, avoiding being stamped on by the Shadow's minion.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, over here! Look at that.
You shrank the wrong man, Drax.
No, I was aiming at you.
Why didn't you shrink the mute? The Tardis door's open.
Right, I've got it. Now listen. One of us creates a diversion and you fly over there and shut the door.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The mute's giant feet pass the little men.

Dialogue.Line: Nasty. Yeah, and we can't use the dimensional stabiliser in here 'cos there's not enough room for when we get back to normal size. We'd just fill up the crack.
Like putty.
Do you mind? Yeah, you've got problems.
Yes. The door's open so the Shadow can go in there and take the Key to Time. Romana can't help and the time loop must be at breaking point by now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Steam is coming out of the Key. Mentalis' countdown is running from 10 to 3 before repeating.

Dialogue.Line: When the countdown reaches zero, up goes Atrios, Zeos and all.
Life presents a dismal picture, you might say.
Yes, you might say that. And of course there's the Marshal.
The Marshal? He's on our side.
No.
No. Oh well. Where's he fit in?
He's in the time loop as well, making a rocket attack on Zeos. Unless, of course, Shapp and Merak get in contact with him.
Where are they?
Back on Atrios, I hope.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The technicians have all left. Merak's head has been bandaged and Shapp has his left arm in a sling.

Dialogue.Line: Atrios control to Marshal. Marshal? Come in, Marshal. Oh, it's useless. He either can't or won't answer. And this time loop device isn't going to hold things back for ever, is it.
No, not unless the Doctor can find the sixth piece, and the sixth piece is somehow connected with Astra.
But she denies all knowledge of it?

All conscious knowledge, yes. But if she's the only one who knows then secret, and if the knowledge is implanted, then it must have affected her, made her different in some slight way that might just show up in analysis.
Yes, but she's not here.
But her records are, on your computer.
Fire!

Dialogue.Character: (The pilot's hand reaches the firing button, then the whole lowering missiles cycle begins again. MARSHAL
Dialogue.Line: Fire!
Well, we've got one thing in our favour. DOCTOR: Oh? DRAX: Mobility. DOCTOR: Mobility. DRAX: Well, if we're only this high, we're practically invisible, aren't we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The mute is still pacing.

Dialogue.Line: Except we daren't move.
Yes. If the Shadow gets the five pieces from the Tardis, which he undoubtedly will, it's up to us to get the sixth piece.
Yeah, but you don't know what it looks like, do ya? I reckon you're banjaxed, my old son. End of the road. Finito.
The Shadow said I'd already seen it. It must be Astra.
Astra?
She must have it. Let's see where this crack leads, shall we?
It's better than getting the boot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The open Tardis is on his screen.

Dialogue.Line: The Doctor has eluded me, but he has made his last mistake. See, the door is open! The Key to Time is mine! Enough! Bwahahahaha!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Shadow leaves, cackling.

Dialogue.Line: He thinks we're just going to stand by and let him walk away with everything we've worked for. Come on, let's get out of here.
In this place.
What?
My destiny is here, in this place. Not on Atrios, not on Zeos. Here.
Astra, listen. You're not under the Shadow's influence any more. Now, let's get out of here before he comes back.
No, I must stay. I am the sixth princess of the sixth dynasty of the sixth Royal House of Atrios.
Yes, yes, but we must get out of here before the Shadow comes back!
This is the time of my becoming, my transcendence.
What are you talking about?
Metamorphosis.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Drax gets a crumpled piece of paper out of his pocket.

Dialogue.Line: Yeah, here we are. Right, now, there's the T junction. Right down to the dungeon, left onto the Shadow's lair.
What? You mean there's a way in he doesn't know about?
Well, it will be when it's finished, but a couple of midgets like us won't be much good on a pick and shovel, will we?
No. No, no. no. But if we get K9 up there, we won't need a pick and shovel, will we. We can still give the Shadow a surprise.
Well, let's normalise then, shall we?
No, no, Drax, no. Small is lovely.
Big is better, though, innit?
Now, the moment I have waited for! Open the door.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The mute pushes the Tardis door, and a bright light shines inside.

Dialogue.Line: Light! Too much light! You, fetch me the Key. Hurry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The mute enters the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: When the Key is mine, I shall dispel the light, and darkness and night shall reign.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The mute returns with the Key, and the Tardis door closes.

Dialogue.Line: Ah.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a hole in the fake sixth part, as if it is disintegrating. The Shadow takes it and leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Destiny. My destiny is near.
Astra, remember you're the sixth princess of the sixth Royal House of the sixth dynasty.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The penny finally drops.

Dialogue.Line: And we're looking for the sixth segment of the Key to Time. Oh, you're in greater danger even than we imagined.
Have you found it?
I think so, yes.
What is it?
A molecular anomaly buried in the genetic structure of the Royal House of Atrios and passed from one generation to the next, until finally, Astra.
What's it mean?
I imagine it means that her every living cell is part of this Key of Time, and that to save us, Astra must be destroyed. You see?
Hey, where are you going?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: We can hear the Doctor and Drax, but not see them.

Dialogue.Line: Everything all right, K9? K9: Affirmative.
Control box in position? K9: Control box in position.
Batteries charged? K9: Affirmative.
Test the blaster, K9.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 fires his laser.

Dialogue.Line: Ow!
Blaster working, K9? K9: Affirmative.
You all right, Drax?
Just about. That bit gets hot.
I'd sit somewhere else, if I were you. Ready, K9? K9: Affirmative.
Now remember, it's absolutely vital to convince the Shadow that you're still under his control. This whole plan depends on how well you can act. Got it? K9: Affirmative, master.
Keep it simple, K9. K9: The Doctor and Drax have been eliminated.
Okay, K9. Now forward. You're on. K9: Master.
Did you ever get to Troy, Drax? Little place in Asia Minor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A mute is on guard outside the transmat cubicle when Astra's circlet is thrown to the floor. It bends, and Merak jumps it from behind, with a weapon.

Dialogue.Line: The third planet. Show me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Merak comes out of the transmat wearing the mute's cloak. He hides as the Shadow processes along with the Key and a train of mutes. He tags on behind and they all enter the lair. The Shadow places the Key on a sort of table, which then lights up a bit.

Dialogue.Line: The fulfillment of that for which I have waited since eternity began.
Preparing for blasting.
You see, Princess, you cannot escape your destiny.
My destiny.
It is for this that you were born. The sixth child of the sixth generation of the sixth dynasty of Atrios. Born to be the sixth and final segment of the Key to Time. Come, Princess, prepare yourself.
I am ready.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Astra reaches for the tracer, and turns into the segment.

Dialogue.Line: Ah!
Astra!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 blasts through the wall, disrupting the Shadow's ecstasy.

Dialogue.Line: What is this? K9: Apologies, master.
You mechanical idiot. K9: But there is an intruder here.
I ordered her to eliminate him. K9: It shall be done.
Wait. Where is the Doctor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 trundles past the Key and turns to face the Shadow.

Dialogue.Line: Ahem. The Doctor and Drax have been eliminated.
Good. Then these two shall stay and witness my moment of glory, my apotheosis. K9: (sotto) Master.
Mine at last!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Shadow reaches for the tracer.

Dialogue.Line: Now, master.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A panel opens in K9's side, and the Doctor and Drax jump out.

Dialogue.Line: No, you'll break the time loop!
Millions will die!
A small beginning. Bwahahahahaha!
The stabiliser, Drax, now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Drax restores the Doctor to normal height, then himself. The Doctor pounces on the sixth segment.

Dialogue.Line: You interfering fool. No one can resist the power of darkness!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor shines the light of the Key into the Shadow's eyes, and he recoils.

Dialogue.Line: Quick, back to the Tardis! Quick!
You go on, Doctor. I'll hold them off.
How will you get back?
The transmat shaft. See you on the Tardis.
Stop him! He must be stopped! Stop him!
Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes inside.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, Merak.
Come on, Romana. Merak, get inside!
No!
Quick, get inside, man!
No, Doctor, I'm staying here.
What!
I'm staying here to look for Astra.
But what about the Shadow?
Astra! Astra!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Merak leaves.

Dialogue.Line: No, Romana, come on.
Set the coordinates for Zeos.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The hole in the fake piece has grown.

Dialogue.Line: We're murderers. First Astra and now Merak.
Romana, it wasn't our idea to use the Royal House of Atrios as carriers, was it?
No, but what happened to Astra was our fault. We're just pawns here to do the Guardian's dirty work.
I don't like it any more than you do, but it's done. Have you set those coordinates yet?
Is that all you can say? She was a living being, and now what is she? A component. And Merak thinks she's still alive. No power should have that right, not even the Guardians. We must do something!
Well, you could start by setting the coordinates for Zeos.
Why?
Romana, you get carried away. If you don't set those coordinates, millions of people will die and this time it really will be our fault. Have you forgotten the time loop?
No, I hadn't forgotten the time loop. Can't you put the new segment in?
In less than a second?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The countdown has reached 1 when the Tardis materialises. The Doctor and Romana rush out.

Dialogue.Line: Quick, cutters. Cutters!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Drax runs in.

Dialogue.Line: Here, what a mess in here.
Listen, Drax. Drax, don't just stand there. What colour?
Green, I think.
What?
Well, it's a long time since I done it. Er.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He searches his pockets.

Dialogue.Line: Quickly, Drax.
Just a minute. Don't fluster me.
Hurry!
I've got a diagram somewhere.
Drax!
Drax!
Drax!
Right.
Drax!
Drax!
Pyramid, green! I told you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor cuts the wire. The countdown goes to zero. And nothing happens.

Dialogue.Line: Well, you didn't have to make such a mess of it all.
Drax. You took your time. Where's K9?
We found young Merak lying there dead to the world. Carrying him slowed us right down.
Really. How is he?
Well, he'll live.
Doctor.
Yes.
Aren't we forgetting something?
I don't think so.
The Marshal!
What? The Marshal.
Come on!
Quick!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They all dash into the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Fire!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Missiles away.

Dialogue.Line: Taste the moment of victory. Any second now, beautiful mushrooms will blossom and burst.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The missiles streak past the planet.

Dialogue.Line: No! No, it's the wrong target!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And blow up the Shadow's satellite instead. KaBOOM!

Dialogue.Line: Sire. Sire. I have failed. The Doctor has accomplished his purpose. He has the Key to Time. I have failed.
I expected no less of you, you whimpering wraith.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Those deep, full tones are those of  Valentine Dyall, voice of Gargravarr, then Deep Thought, and the original Man in Black.

Dialogue.Line: But your death is already encompassed in my designs, for now the Doctor shall release the Key to me, and chaos shall break upon the universe!
What a shot, Marshal! Ha, ha, well shot!
Doctor, he hit the planet of evil and he was aiming at Zeos!
Well, I can't help what he was aiming at.
What did you do?
A mere nothing. A mere deflective forcefield set up for a millisecond set up between the Marshal and Zeos, bounced the missiles smack onto the planet of evil.
Is that all?
Yes.
Well, he might have told us, mightn't he, dog? We was expecting to get blasted into infinity. K9: Affirmative.
Well, I'm sorry about that. I don't know what I'm apologising for. I just saved your lives! Can I drop you somewhere, Drax?
No thanks. I've got a contract job on down there.
Contract job? No armaments, I hope.
No. Reconstruction, war damage, scrap and that. Me and the Marshal's going fifty-fifty.
You and the Marshal?
Yeah, well, he's out of a job now, isn't he. I mean, no war, no job, so I took him on.
When did you arrange this?
In about half an hour's time, I should think.
I see. Fifty-fifty?
Well, sixty-forty, know what I mean?
Ah.
And if you ever want to get rid of that thing (the complete Key) just let me know, won't you.
I'll let you know. Bye, bye, Drax.
Right then. Bye all.
Goodbye.
Remember me to Gallifrey.
Bye, bye, Drax.
Goodbye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Drax leaves. Romana closes the doors.

Dialogue.Line: Right, I'll set the coordinates for Gallifrey, shall I?
Why Gallifrey?
Well, that's where we're going, isn't it?
We have the power to do anything we like. Absolute power over every particle in the universe. Everything that has ever existed or ever will exist. As from this moment are you listening to me, Romana?
Yes, of course I'm listening.
Because if you're not listening I can make you listen, because I can do anything.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor rolls his eyes back like a maniac.

Dialogue.Line: As from this moment there's no such thing as free will in the entire universe. There's only my will, because I possess the Key to Time!
Doctor, are you all right?

(normal) Well of course I'm all right. But supposing I wasn't all right. This thing makes me feel in such a way I'd be very worried if I felt like that about someone else feeling like this about that. Do you understand?
Yes.
What do you understand?
That the sooner we hand this over to the White Guardian
The better!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dramatic organ chords, and the Guardian appears on the scanner, dressed in white.

Dialogue.Line: My congratulations to you, Doctor.
Oh, thank you, sir, thank you. GUARDIAN [on scanner]: You performed your task with admirable dispatch. The universe has much to thank you for.
Well, it was a pleasure, sir. Wasn't it a pleasure, Romana?
Doctor, that's not the President.
What's the President got to do with it? GUARDIAN [on scanner]: I can change my form or shape at will, my dear child. I appeared to you as the President so as not to alarm you.
Just be careful who you're talking to.
Sorry, I GUARDIAN [on scanner]: You have the Key to Time, Doctor?
Ah. Oh, I have, I have indeed, sir. Do you like it? GUARDIAN [on scanner]: Do I like it? Yes, yes, I suppose you could say that I like it.
Yes, we're very proud of it, sir. Aren't we, Romana, proud of it?
What? Oh, yes, yes.

What happens now, sir? You said, if I remember in our first conversation, that once it was assembled it would stop the entire universe and enable you to restore the natural balances of good and evil throughout the whole of the universe. GUARDIAN [on scanner]: That is correct, Doctor. So, will you release the Key to me that I may do this?
Certainly, sir, yes, certainly, of course. Key to Time, I command you. Could I ask you something, sir? GUARDIAN [on scanner]: Yes, Doctor?

It's just that, well, the Key is already assembled, sir. I mean, couldn't you restore the balances now? GUARDIAN [on scanner]: Yes, Doctor, but I must have the Key for safe keeping. It is an awesomely powerful key.

Oh yes, sir, yes, and mustn't be allowed to fall into the wrong hands. I quite understand, sir, yes. Key to Time, I command. What about the sixth segment? GUARDIAN [on scanner]: What about it, Doctor?

Well, I mean, as you know, sir, the sixth segment was in fact a human being, and I mean, if the pieces are maintained in their present pattern it means that she'll be imprisoned forever, sir. GUARDIAN [on scanner]: That is, of course, regrettable.
Very regrettable. GUARDIAN [on scanner]: But with the fate of the universe at stake.
Quite. You can't be too careful. I quite understand. Key to Time, I command that you stay exactly where you are!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hits a Tardis control.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor! You have fully activated all the Tardis' defences!

We can't be too careful, can we? And it would be a terrible tragedy for the universe if it suddenly turned out that I was colour blind. GUARDIAN [on scanner]: Doctor, release the Key to me immediately!
Unable to distinguish between the White Guardian and the Black Guardian.
Doctor, what do you mean?
Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Guardian snarls and turns into a negative of its former image.

Dialogue.Line: Don't you see? The White Guardian would never have had such a callous disregard for human life.
Of course. Astra, the sixth segment. He would have dispersed it immediately. GUARDIAN [on scanner]: Doctor, you shall die for this!

I think not. Remember, the Key to Time is still mine, rage all you like. GUARDIAN [on scanner]: I shall destroy you for this! I will disperse every particle of your being to the furthest reaches of eternity!
Ah well, I wish I could stay and watch you try, but you know how it is. Places to go, people to see, things to do. Romana?
Yes?
When I give the signal
Yes?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor reaches for the tracer.

Dialogue.Line: Dematerialise.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He takes the tracer from the Key.

Dialogue.Line: Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And snaps the tracer in two. The first five pieces of the Key hurtle off into time and space, and the sixth becomes Astra again.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, Merak.
Astra? Astra, where are you?
I'm here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She takes his hand.

Dialogue.Line: Astra.
You see? I think of everything.
Doctor?
Hmm?
What exactly have you done with the Key to Time?
Key to Time? Oh, well, I just scattered it round through space and time.
I see. So where are we going?
Going? I don't know.
You have absolutely no sense of responsibility whatsoever.
What?
You're capricious, arrogant, self-opinionated, irrational and you don't even know where we're going.
Exactly.
What?
Well, if I knew where I was going, there'd be a chance the Black Guardian would, too.
Oh.
Hence this new device.
What is it?
Well, it's called a randomiser and it's fitted to the guidance system and operates under a very complex scientific principle called pot luck.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sets the Tardis going.

Dialogue.Line: Now no one knows where we're going. Not even the Black Guardian.
Not even us.
